item.title: Reminder that we already have AGI — 16 replies — 64.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Reminder that we already have AGI

Open thread • Replies: 16 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:59 UTC

OP

Early replies (first 3)

61889716
>>61889694
Worldcoin kek.

61889719
>>61889694

61889731
>>61889694
it was possible in 2025, it's definitely coming in 2026, get up to date on market speak noobfaggot

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61892250
>>61889694
he meant anal gay intercourse, and it's the only true statement he ever made in his entire life

61893402
>>61889731
It isn't coming. LLMs are useful for some things but the notion that they are going to anything other than a glorified search engine needs to die. Yeah they are good a being a search engine, search engines are useful, but they suffer from the same problems as search engines, namely that a internet search can never actually tell you if the information it find is accurate.

Research needs to look an entirely different direction if they want true intelligence. We've been working on text generators for decades so it shouldn't be surprising that we've managed to perfect them, but the next breakthrough is going to come from something else we've been working on for decades, not from incremental improvements to LLMs.

Who knows, maybe LLMs can aid in the research of this alternative field which will bring the next advancement? Using better technology to do research can cut down the years required so the accelerated nature of technology remains, but it is still going to come from somewhere people aren't expecting.

LLMs can still be useful, but the costs associated with it are going to become prohibitive. Eventually they are going to just be like railways or telecoms which serve as an expensive base over which the next thing can emerge.

61893571
AGI is here as of two months ago, it's openclaw when using anything smarter than Opus 4.5. Companies are beginning to hire mac minis instead of people. If you still want to meme about r's in strawberry and pretend this isn't happening, that's at your own risk. You'll be out of a job sooner rather than later. My "glorified search engine" just built a whole tradingview clone for me and i cancelled my subscription.

61893608
ps, you should download a copy of the tradingview free charting library now. Because once they notice the potential damage it'll cause to their subscription profits they'll move it behind a B2B paywall

61893618
>>61889716
Lololol

61893632
>>61893571
>job
Sir this is a business and finance board

61893850
>>61893571
Producing a charting library for you is indeed a "glorified search engine". Impressive no doubt, but all it really is doing is copying something that already exists. Like you said it wouldn't work without the library. So it is just searching and displaying things in a proper way. This seems very "Star Trek" where you can command a computer to display stuff for you, but it is still an unthinking computer doing this. It is not AGI, it is going to do a particular sets of tasks extraordinarily well, but it can't do everything.

Incidentally in terms of the economics of computing, having everyone needing to use an LLM to produce their own software clone is enormously inefficient. It makes sense right now only for two reasons:

1. Using AI is basically "free" for the end user. They aren't paying any associated costs yet.

2. Software is currently held back behind paywalls creating artificial scarcity.

AI in practice is unlocking tons of value that is blocked by intellectual property laws, but getting around intellectual property laws is coming at the expense of mounting physical costs. We could have Free Software that is made efficiently and given away for cheap and that would be far less resource intensive that using LLMs to make personalized versions of everything for everyone.

It is a bit like the phenomena of computers constantly bloating in memory requirements because they have greater capacities. Old software was incredibly efficient, using only kilobytes, but now it uses gigabytes. AI produced software is using terrabytes. This trend will continue until our software demands become impossible to fufill in the real world.

In Computer Science there is a concept of complexity, which is how quickly something grows when its unit demands increase, and in some cases it might be linear, quadratic, or exponential. Other cases it is logarithmic and it is proportionally less intensive the more it is used. While now we are "hyperscaling", that can't last forever.

61894075
>>61893850
> all it really is doing is copying something that already exists
that's not how ai works. It learns the probability of existing text patterns from training data, and then uses those probabilities to output original text. Which isn't the same as copypasting existing github repos

and that chart library is only like half my codebase. It got the app up and running quickly but if I wanted to I could have the ai replace that file in a day or two

61894111
Whether it's the US or China who reaches AGI first, they will not be making it public nor implement it into public LLMs for a very long time. The military and intel community will get first dibs for national security reasons

61896793
>>61889694
AI bubble is going to pop buddy

61896825
>>61889694
Why pay agi when you can unperson those who won't work and don't provide value?

61896837
>>61893571
based, did you use lightweight charts? i want to do this so i can make tick charts without paying out the ass for them, but i haven't yet. its truly incredible what a smart person and ai can do together. the things im doing with efficient regularization are pretty crazy, i doubt i'd ever have the patience to do it on my own, much better to be an idiot ceo telling the hyper competent assistant to make it work.

61897201
>>61896837
Yeah that's the library. You still have to provide the OHLC candle data yourself though. Key is to look for newish API providers that don't have 50 years of history squeezing out profits and enshittifying their services. Stocks have a lot of dinosaur APIs that will cost a ton. But most crypto exchanges give away their entire candle database for free.

This project took me just over a month using free plan antigravity. Their weekly quota lasted me 4 hours of Gemini 3 pro, plus a few hits of opus 4.5. If you have a paid plan it would go much faster, maybe even overnight. And both those models are obsolete now lol

item.title: The War with Iran — 8 replies — 32.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
The War with Iran

Open thread • Replies: 8 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:54 UTC

OP

A geopolitical risk premium is priced-in to all parts of this market right now.

We see a 3 different potential scenarios:

1. US makes deal with Iran: Stocks rise, commodities fall

2. US does "one-time" strike with Iran: Brief volatility which ends with stocks rising, commodities falling

3. US enters prolonged war with Iran: Stocks fall, commodities rise

Our positions win in 2 of the 3 scenarios outlined above, which we believe are more likely than #3.

If the US truly is setting up for a long war with Iran, then this would be highly bearish for equities, bullish for crude and gold.

Why don't we think this is the case?

President Trump wants $2/gallon gas and wants to be the "Peace President." None of these objectives are obtained in a prolonged war with Iran, particularly with mid-term elections on the horizon.

That is our current mindset on how we are approaching this market.

61896947
>>61895162
XRP is natively used on the XRP in cross minted asset swaps at a fraction of the cost and speed of off or cross ledger settlement with basically bottomless on demand liquidity so that low volume corridors don't get blown out and weird continuous markets don't need to be developed for an efficient universal system. XRP also has none of the risk inherent in smart contracts, is completely counterparty-less and using ILP the whole thing can scale to literally trillions of tps with fees paid in any currency, capable of micropayment batching. XRP is less risky, has no counterparty or contract risk and scales liquidity regardless of the currency pair instantly with no need to establish liquidity between the currency pairs let alone specific issuer walled garden tokens (USDC vs. USDT vs. RLUSD vs. every other national etc. stablecoin) and costs less and finalizes faster. Literally every single reason they would be considering is better done this way, with a few frictions as technically possible with current DLT and zero middlemen unless they choose to have them, completely decentralized, being able to atomic swap on ILP through their own chosen structure.
